name: Rogue State
description: Assume control of a Middle Eastern country recovering from a violent revolution. It is up to you: Forge alliances, grow your economy, invade your neighbors, or pacify your population. Rogue State is a geopolitical strategy game that will force you to always stay one step ahead of your rivals to survive.

reviews.review_text: While the concept is interesting, drawing from the same idea of games such as Balance of Power, there is just not much depth to this game. While it promises a branching option for governing in reality it is just a numbers game and lacks any real sense of weight or consequence for doing anything.

A fun concoction of Capitalism3 x Tropico set in middle east!   At first i was pretty skeptical at the look of things and it seemed slightly shallow, but as i played the depth of gameplay was slowly unraveled. Its simplified, but actually very fun and rewarding. Plenty of valid playstyles by the looks of it, somewhat randomised starting conditions for assuring of the replay value, aswell as rewards for previously 'won' games.   Some thing are not clear to me, like i was never able to ' win ' a speech, even tho those were the actual things my country needed the most. There is 1 resource lacking in gameplay by the looks of it ( in one game start i didnt have anyone selling precious metals). Cant seem to interract with UN either. I probably just missed something or didnt play enough.   This genuinely feels like a pretty damn fun game for people who enjoy this kinda thing, - sitting in an office, managing the country. Im just getting started with this one but i already want to see more from these developers. There are far too few good games like this to pass this one.
A welcome addition to the pitifully small library of political/management sims.

Rogue State... the humoristic post-revolution country management simulator.  A nice idea, layout and attempt to deliver a realistic experience but the game have not what it takes to give us sufficient interest and life span.  [Game refunded: Review won't be updated]    Plot:

I played Democracy 3 and thought this is just another political simulator game with more graphic and less choice. I reload many times to get oil. I ruled as a leader of the nation and struggle with tax and approving rates. I try to make the 'right' choice and calculate the consequence. I feel nothing. Until that fateful day,   when tariq walk into my office. Tariq... I never know... my loyal assistant and friend... you should have told me... I know I would regret... but this is too important...... And then everything make sense. As I sit alone in the office with no one to summon and no one to talk to.    I realize I am a dictator after all. Loniness is the price I pay for power. I feel sad.
That game is awesome i love game like this. This is basically Assad Simulator :-)

! I GOT A KEY FROM THE DEVELOPER, MY REVIEW MAY BE DIFFERENT HENCE ME NOT PAYING THE 13 DOLLAR ASKING PRICE !  After one playthrough of the game, I can say that the game isn't worth the asking price. Maybe 10 dollars, but 13 is steep.  The gameplay is very difficult. I got destroyed. A terrorist group executed me because the liberals got mad. It's very fun, and I recommend it.  The hardest part of this review is that I don't recommend this game for the asking price of 13 dollars, but I DO recommend it for the fun, strategic gameplay.

Contrary to what many analyzes are saying, this game is repetitive, with limited options and nowhere near resembles the Civ as says the analysis of Haogamers: 'I highly, highly recommend Rogue State to all fans of Civ and anyone looking for a real challenge.'   The idea behind the game is rather good, but I do not think that this is a finished game.   Trade is extremely limited not about to be difficult, but being poorly prepared, not to mention that you can not make 'deals' and proposals, just accept.   Interactions with other countries (3 fictitious, US and UN only) is minimal.   The internal policies of the country appear to be unbalanced and not 'update' their situation in the game.   Do not recommend buying, I've asked my refund.
Well replayable, thanks to random start settings.
Pretty good addition to the painfully tiny library of political simulations. I'd like to see more detail to the game, but otherwise decent.
It's very simmiler to democracy 3 but far less complicated and better for the casual player.
>Free nation from evil tyrant >Create liberal utopia >Find oil >USA want oil >USA invades  10/10 would embrace democracy again

Basically I keep wishing this game was like King of Dragon Pass. You can't really do anything with your nation beyond a few 30 or so options that can only happen once, basically once you reach the max height of power in the game there's nothing to do.

It's fun to be the dictator of 'Not Iraq we Totally Swear You Guys.' The bad animation and mostly-text gameplay gives it a sort of retro early 90's feel to it, and the idea of growing a nation is fun, though the process doesn't seem very long. The game's pretty diverse and I just finished my first playthrough in four hours. I'll probably do a second playthrough later on, so I'd say there's at least a LITTLE replay value to this game.  7/10, dissapointed that the logo is not a corgi, even though it looks like one.
This game is like a flash-game version of Tropico. Not worth the price, and not nearly as good as Tropico is.

Doesn't really make much sense. Highly skeptical of all these glowing reviews here.   Just no feedback to any of your actions, crappy voice acting and animations, no sense that you're really 'doing' anything.
I somehow managed to upset both the religious fundamentalists and the liberals. I wasn't even made when they blew my Escalade up after getting that right.
